content.heading: Reduce Your Speed
content.text: In winter conditions, your stopping distance can be up to 10 times longer than on dry roads. Always drive slower than you would in summer.
tips: Reduce speed by at least 20-30% in snow
Reduce speed by 50% or more on ice
Speed limits are maximums, not targets

content.heading: Increase Following Distance
content.text: Keep at least 4-6 seconds of distance to the car in front of you. This gives you time to react and stop safely.
tips: Use the '4 second rule' - count seconds after the car ahead passes a landmark
Double this distance in heavy snow or ice

content.heading: Smooth Movements
content.text: Avoid sudden movements of the steering wheel, accelerator, or brakes. Smooth, gradual inputs help maintain traction.
tips: Accelerate gently from stops
Brake gradually, never slam the brakes
Steer smoothly without jerky movements

content.heading: ABS Braking
content.text: Modern cars have ABS (Anti-lock Braking System). When braking on slippery surfaces, press the brake firmly and hold it - let the ABS do its job. You may feel pulsing in the pedal; this is normal.
tips: Press and hold the brake firmly
Don't pump the brakes with ABS
Keep steering while braking

content.heading: Engine Braking
content.text: Use engine braking by shifting to a lower gear (or using 'B' mode in automatics). This slows the car without using the brakes and reduces the risk of wheel lock.
tips: Downshift gradually on hills
Use engine braking before curves

content.heading: What is Black Ice?
content.text: Black ice is a thin, nearly invisible layer of ice on the road. It's called 'black' because you can see the dark road surface through it. It's extremely slippery and often catches drivers by surprise.
tips: Most common in early morning and evening
Forms on bridges, overpasses, and shaded areas first
Watch for glossy patches on the road

content.heading: If You Hit Black Ice
content.text: Stay calm. Don't brake or steer suddenly. Take your foot off the accelerator and let the car slow naturally. Keep the steering wheel straight until you regain traction.
tips: Don't panic - stay calm
Ease off the accelerator
Keep the wheel straight
Don't brake unless absolutely necessary

content.heading: Steep Hills & Passes
content.text: Norwegian mountain roads can have steep gradients. Use low gear when going downhill to control speed. Never coast in neutral.
tips: Use low gear (1, 2, or L) on steep descents
Don't ride the brakes - they can overheat
Pull over at designated rest areas if needed

content.heading: Single Lane Roads
content.text: Many mountain roads are single-lane with passing places. The car going uphill generally has right of way. Pull into passing places to let others pass.
tips: Look ahead for passing places
Reverse to a passing place if needed
Flash lights to signal you're letting someone pass

content.heading: Kolonnekjoring (Convoy Driving)
content.text: In severe weather, roads may only be open for convoy driving - you follow a snowplow in a group. Check road status before driving.
tips: Check vegvesen.no or the 175 app for road status
Wait at the convoy meeting point
Never try to overtake the convoy

content.heading: Blood Alcohol Limit
content.text: Norway has one of the strictest drink-driving laws in Europe. The legal limit is 0.02% BAC - effectively zero tolerance. Penalties include heavy fines, license suspension, and even imprisonment.
tips: 0.02% limit - even one drink can put you over
If you drink, don't drive at all
Penalties are severe: fines, jail, license loss

content.heading: Headlights Always On
content.text: You must drive with headlights on at all times in Norway, day and night, all year round.
tips: Use dipped/low beam headlights
Check lights are working before your trip

content.heading: Speed Limits
content.text: Speed limits in Norway are generally lower than other European countries. Common limits: 50 km/h in towns, 80 km/h on rural roads, 90-110 km/h on highways.
tips: Fines are based on income and can be very high
Speed cameras are common
Limits are maximums - reduce in bad weather

content.heading: Emergency Numbers
content.text: In case of emergency, call these numbers immediately:
tips: 112 - Police
113 - Ambulance
110 - Fire
These numbers work from any phone

content.heading: If You Get Stuck
content.text: If your car gets stuck in snow or you slide off the road, stay calm and assess the situation.
tips: Turn on hazard lights
Stay in the car if it's cold outside
Call for help: roadside assistance or 112
Keep emergency kit: warm clothes, blanket, water, snacks

content.heading: Viking Roadside Assistance
content.text: Most rental cars in Norway include Viking roadside assistance. Check your rental agreement for the phone number. They can help with breakdowns, flat tires, and getting unstuck.
tips: Keep the Viking number saved in your phone
Typical number: 06000 or check rental papers

content.heading: The Polar Night (Mørketid)
content.text: In Northern Norway above the Arctic Circle, the sun doesn't rise for weeks during winter. In Tromsø, polar night lasts from late November to mid-January. Even outside this period, daylight hours are very short.
tips: Tromsø has no sunrise from Nov 21 to Jan 21
The 'blue light' of polar twilight can be deceptively dim
Your perception of distance and speed changes in constant darkness

content.heading: Headlight Strategy
content.text: In total darkness, your headlights are your lifeline. Use low beams in built-up areas and high beams on open roads — but be ready to switch quickly.
tips: Always use low beam in towns and when meeting traffic
Switch to high beam on open roads with no oncoming cars
Keep headlights and windscreen clean — salt and grime reduce visibility fast
Use fog lights only in fog or heavy snowfall

content.heading: Fatigue & Alertness
content.text: Driving in continuous darkness is mentally exhausting. Your body's circadian rhythm is disrupted, and drowsiness is a serious risk.
tips: Take breaks every 1-2 hours — stop, stretch, get fresh air
Don't drive if you feel drowsy — find a safe place to rest
Keep the car slightly cool to stay alert
Avoid heavy meals before driving

content.heading: Reindeer — The Arctic Highway Hazard
content.text: Reindeer roam freely across roads in Northern Norway. They are semi-domesticated by Sámi herders and have no fear of cars. If you see one, expect more to follow.
tips: Reindeer often travel in herds — if one crosses, slow down and wait
Most common at dawn, dusk, and during polar twilight
Reduce speed near warning signs (yellow triangle with reindeer)
They may freeze in headlights — honk gently and wait

content.heading: Moose — Large and Dangerous
content.text: Moose (elg) are the largest animals in Scandinavia and a collision can be fatal. An adult moose weighs 400-500 kg and stands taller than a car.
tips: Moose are most active at dawn and dusk
Watch the ditches and forest edges alongside the road
If a collision is unavoidable, brake hard but don't swerve into oncoming traffic
Report any wildlife collision to police: 112

content.heading: What To Do After a Wildlife Collision
content.text: If you hit an animal, stop safely, turn on hazard lights, and call the police at 02800 (non-emergency) or 112 if anyone is injured.
tips: Stop and secure the area with hazard lights and warning triangle
Call police at 02800 or 112 for injuries
Note the exact location (GPS coordinates or road markers)
Never approach an injured moose or reindeer

content.heading: Extreme Cold (-20°C and Below)
content.text: Temperatures in Northern Norway can drop to -20°C or lower. Extreme cold affects your car, your tires, and your body. Diesel cars can struggle to start, batteries drain faster, and tire pressure drops.
tips: Always keep the fuel tank at least half full
Park facing away from the wind to protect the engine
Carry extra warm clothing, a blanket, and a thermos
Check that the rental car has an engine block heater

content.heading: Whiteout & Blizzard Conditions
content.text: Arctic blizzards can reduce visibility to near zero in seconds. Drifting snow and strong winds create 'whiteout' conditions where you cannot see the road.
tips: If visibility drops suddenly, slow down gradually — don't brake hard
Turn on fog lights and hazard lights
Follow the road markers (snow poles with reflectors)
If you can't see at all, pull off the road safely and wait it out

content.heading: Strong Crosswinds
content.text: Exposed coastal and mountain roads in Northern Norway are hit by powerful Arctic winds. Bridges, fjord crossings, and high plateaus are especially dangerous.
tips: Reduce speed on exposed sections — especially bridges and headlands
Grip the steering wheel firmly with both hands
Be prepared for sudden gusts when exiting tunnels
Check yr.no for wind forecasts before driving exposed routes
